urn:contentItem:5P7S-HYP1-JB20-G2NS-00000-00Andrew Sheets and Julian David Intvd on Bloomberg TV2017-08-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:40ZLexisNexisBLOOMBERG TV12:00 AM ESTAndrew Sheets, Julian DavidNEWSInternational081197cb.550Andrew Sheets and Julian David Intvd on Bloomberg TVGuy Johnson, Matt Miller, Alan Crawford, David Rocks

Discussion on global markets, technology, and geopolitics.

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

ANDREW SHEETS, CHIEF CROSS ASSET STRATEGIST, MORGAN STANLEY & JULIAN DAVID, CEO, TECHUK, ARE INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TV

AUGUST 11, 2017

SPEAKERS: ANDREW SHEETS, CHIEF CROSS ASSET STRATEGIST, MORGAN STANLEY

JULIAN DAVID, CEO, TECHUK

GUY JOHNSON, BLOOMBERG NEWS

MATT MILLER, BLOOMBERG NEWS

ALAN CRAWFORD, BLOOMBERG NEWS

DAVID ROCKS, SENIOR EDITOR, BLOOMBERG BUSINESSWEEK

[*] JOHNSON: Joining us now, Andrew Sheets, chief cross asset strategist at Morgan Stanley. Good morning. Which is the bigger factor for the market today, inflation number coming out a little bit later on or what's happening on the geopolitical front?

SHEETS: I think geopolitics have really taken -- taken the lead here. I think if you would ask investors on Monday, it was absolutely around CPI, it would be absolutely around, you know, the timing of -- of a Fed action and what we might see, but I think the moves -- the rhetoric that we've seen out of Washington and North Korea, that has I think, been the predominant factor now dominating markets.

JOHNSON: Just to kind of take a step back, nobody's here, these are thinned markets. The president's, theoretically, on holiday, is it just the fact that -- that we are in holiday liquidity sort of environments in - - in various asset classes that is -- that is driving this kind of pickup in volatility?

SHEETS: Well, look, I mean, I think that's -- that's actually a really important point, right? As -- as silly as it might sound that kind of where people currently are, are a bigger factor than some of these macroeconomic events. The fact that August is a time when a lot of people are out that we are seeing the -- the president and his staff are not in the White House, that investors often have to deal with markets with thinner liquidity and thinner markets in August, has a tendency to exacerbate moves. And I think that's maybe one reason why historically, you tend to see somewhat weaker market performance in August relative to other months.

MILLER: So you think we're going to see a pickup then in volatility? Are we going to -- I mean, the other day, we were making a massive deal about the S&P 500 being down 0.24 percent, are we going to start seeing 1 percent moves again, real -- real range?

SHEETS: So I would actually be a little bit skeptical about that. So look, you -- you obviously have had a big shock to a market that was incredibly calm. So right, as of Monday, the 10-year -- the 10-day realized volatility for the S&P 500 was just 2 or 3 percent, it was the lowest in 50 years. So it's definitely a shock for the market to go from that level of calm to what we have currently, but if I think about the factors that are still in place, I think you still are dealing with relatively solid global growth, you're s till dealing with very dovish policy. Most of the positioning metrics that we track don't suggest investors are unusually long. I think all of those things argue against a really large regime shift into kind of daily 1, 1.5 percent moves.

MILLER: One of the things -- one of the factoids I saw recently in a story about how quant hedge fund strategies are failing because there's not enough dumb money out there is that, retail investors' cash levels are at the lowest they've been in a decade. If they've -- if they've already -- if they're already so invested or it doesn't matter I guess, where they're invested, do you expect them to maybe be pulling money out then? Especially as we see highs like this?

SHEETS: Well, look, I mean, I think this is a debate where you can find data on -- on either side, so I guess what -- what I find a little bit more encouraging is that if we look at flows into the equity market, especially the U.S. equity market, those flows have still been incredibly modest, not just over the last year, but really over the last eight years. So I don't yet see evidence, and I think, you know, our -- our U.S. equity strategist very much agree with this. We don't see evidence that retail has rushed a lot of money into the market recently that it would then need to pull out. So -- so look, there's always -- you know, I certainly wouldn't say that investors were negative, you know, in the last several months, but we don't see that sign of excessive stock buying that would lead we think, to excessive retail selling.

JOHNSON: This is definitely the wrong chart, what I'm about to show here. Let's talk about -- a little bit about the skew and what's going on. The market is -- is positioning itself to buy kind of downside protection at the moment. The -- the -- the line goes up, as it goes up, basically, that's signaling that the market is trying to buy downside protection. Is that an opportunity do you think at this point when you're looking at what is happening with the SPX? Would you be going the other way?

SHEETS: Yes. Well, look, I think that's -- that's a really important part, right? So as much as, you know, the -- the focus has been on the rhetoric in Korea or the -- the daily moves in the S&P that the much bigger moves we've had over the last 48 hours have really been in the VIX, and volatility on the VIX, right, which have moved significantly more than you would usually expect. And you know, that suggest that that's maybe where the real market pressure is, where some of the real market inefficiency might be, and it's not just mood volatility significantly, but as you mentioned it's moved skew significantly, right? So you've seen the volatility on puts rise to relatively unusually high levels versus calls. So you know, in our view, probably, the best way to lean against that would be, that that makes calls relatively cheap, because that's the volatility that's lowest relative to everything else.

MILLER: All right, Andrew, you're going to stick with us here. Andrew Sheets is chief -- chief cross asset strategist at Morgan Stanley. There's a lot to talk about on a day like today when we see actual movement in equity index.

(BREAK)

MILLER: Joining us here to talk about that in Berlin is our government editor, Alan Crawford. Andrew Sheets is with us as well, chief cross asset strategist at Morgan Stanley. Alan, let's talk -- touch on the first point. And I think a lot of Germans find it hard to sort of discern now between the policies of the two parties. What would change say, if the SPD won and Martin Schultz came in Angela Merkel's place, policy-wise?

CRAWFORD: Well, at the moment, that looks like a big if, but it would also depend very much on what kind of coalition he could form. At the moment, that latest poll suggests it would have to be something like a four-way coalition, so it's extremely hard to see. Nevertheless, what we could see is that Martin Schulz as a former president of the European Parliament, he's somewhat more open to certainly common European policies, so perhaps more in terms of defense sharing and crucially perhaps, more in terms of integrating the Eurozone. Merkel has also made some comments about that, that she's open to some of these moves by the -- the French president, but the -- the assumption is that Schultz would probably be somewhat more open. Whether that extends to debt sharing is a different issue, but yes, more open.

JOHNSON: So it's hers to lose at this point in time, now that I think it's clear judging by the polling, Alan, so what risks is she running, kind of -- and -- and how does that relate to the strategy that we're seeing?

CRAWFORD: Well, as we just mentioned, we're talking about party certainly, party officials are somewhat concerned about any -- any hint of complacency. Not so much on Merkel's behalf but more like on behalf of the party and the party apparatus. Remember of course, when Merkel first ran for Chancellor in 2005, she was running Gerhard Schroder who was the incumbent -- he was the chancellor, and she managed to -- to squander a lead of more than 20 percentage points. He of course, was an extremely adept campaigner, and it was -- and in the end, she one by one point. Nevertheless, she is embarking on 50-stop campaign tour, so I think it's hard to accuse her of complacency at this point.

MILLER: You're welcome to refresh or memories. I mean, not all of us wrote a book on Angela Merkel. I should point out that Alan wrote a book on Merkel, so he knows this subject better than anyone. Andrew, let me ask you from an investor's perspective, is this an important election for you to pay close attention to? I mean, do you have to be as concerned about this as you did the French elections or the Dutch elections, or can you pretty much consider this a confirmation of Angela Merkel's fourth term and that kind consistency is good for you as an investor?

SHEETS: Well, look, so I -- I think about it as -- as follows. I think in terms of the actual outcome, I think markets are probably going to focus on it somewhat less because of what we've already seen in the Netherlands and France, and because I think there's a broad majority within Germany that -- that is pro-Europe, pro the E.U., and is pushing towards more integrations, that whole argument that there might be some faction pushing for something different now, seems significantly less likely. But I think what markets will focus on is this idea that at the core of Europe in -- between France and Germany, this idea of really working for a stronger European union, are pushed towards reform that we might not have seen in a way that we have in a number of years. I think that's structurally bullish for the euro, that's been one of the key calls of our FX strategy team, and the euro remains very undervalued on a long-term basis, and so this is a multi-year call in our view, for a stronger euro.

JOHNSON: Alan, where does the risk lie to Europe in this election? There does seem to be this sense that coming out of this, we're going to see a new impetus towards a closer integration. Now, that's started by Mr. Macron, but the German election's a pivotal piece in all of this. Does the coalition formation have a bearing on that? I.e., if she's in -- in -- in coalition with the -- with the FDP for instance, would that dilute that drive?

CRAWFORD: This is exactly the point that we will be focusing on during our coverage. The -- the latest poll for example, showed that Merkel has various coalition options which could in turn strengthen her hand in negotiations which remember, tend to last several weeks, if not months in Germany, after the election. Yes, the free democrats with whom had her second term coalition, they are -- they're more skeptical in terms of euro are bailouts, in terms of -- in terms of more integration in the Eurozone, that could put a break on some of her plans. Equally, the Greens are also in play. They are somewhat more enthusiastic about Eurozone integration and essentially, helping others. There could be a three-way coalition which is untested at the Federal level, or it could be an underground coalition.

MILLER: I remember when Joschka Fischer who was -- who's arguably, one of the most famous Greens said, forget about it, we prefer to wear dreadlocks, and they wouldn't be able to deal with that. Something like that, I'm paraphrasing. But it is a possible coalition. What's the -- what's the -- what are the dangers to Merkel here, and what could bring her down in the next six weeks? Is diesel a problem for her, is -- is the refugee, I would say crisis, but it's no longer a crisis here in Germany, is the influx that we saw a couple of years ago of refugees a problem for her? What could bring her down?

CRAWFORD: That's definitely an Achilles heel. If there were -- if there were to be some massive influx to Germany such as we saw two years ago when there was a genuine crisis and a buildup of people at Germany's border, that -- at the moment, the focus is on Italy, so it looks somewhat less likely, but nevertheless, if she was forced to make some kind of snap decision about that, then that would be a problem for her. Who that would benefit, whether it would benefit her main rival is another issue. Certainly, there's also, if there were any sort of repeat of the -- of the sexual attacks in Cologne, that was a devastating issue related to the crisis. Of course, terrorism is always -- is always lurking. Again, it's hard to see how these issues could -- could boost support for her -- her -- her main rival. The one thing I would say is, there is a potential that support for the -- the far right, anti-immigration AfD Party, perhaps the polls are underestimating that. I'm not saying it could win, but there is importantly the level, higher.

MILLER: The polls here though, historically more accurate than they are say, in Britain. Alan Crawford, our European government editor here in Berlin. I should point out that he co-wrote the book, "Angela Merkel: A Chancellor Forged in Crisis" with Tony Czuczka who also works with us here in Berlin. Andrew Sheets is the chief crosset (ph) asset -- cross asset strategist at Morgan Stanley, he's going to stick with us, our guest host for the hour.

(BREAK)

JOHNSON: Let's turn our attention now to market risks and how investors should be positioning themselves. Alan Sheets chief cross asset strategist at Morgan Stanley is still with us, and let's talk about some of the calls that we should be making right now. Andrew, the world is long euro, is that the right call?

SHEETS: Yes. So we think from an equity perspective, not necessarily. Graham Secker, our European equity strategist has been somewhat cautious over the last several months on concerns around what the strong euro will mean for earnings. Now, I think what's quite interesting is just really, over the last day, some of the tactical indicators that his team follows have finally dipped down into bi-territory, so that's something we have to watch in terms of our relative preferences. Currently, the U.S. and Japan are our top global equity markets, but Europe has underperformed recently, and that's something we have to monitor.

MILLER: Why are you long European value versus growth right now, Andrew?

SHEETS: Sure. So look, I think the -- the argument for Europe is that you have an improving economy and that valuations are attractive, that I think is the dominant narrative that I hear for European equities. I think if we look deeper into the market, most of the value in Europe lies within value, it lies within the financial sector, it lies within the energy sector, it lies within some of the other parts that make up the value index. So in our view, that's the part of the market where the majority of the cheapness of Europe is concentrated. It's starting to get some positive momentum on a long-term basis, it's underperformed really, for a decade and we think that's starting to turn around in our long-term view.

JOHNSON: Why are you short U.K. inflation? Why are you short the U.K. 10-year breakeven?

SHEETS: Sure. So -- so we think Brexit remains a challenging dynamic, right, and you're going to have U.K. politicians coming back from their holidays, going into negotiations in September, and we expect potentially more negative news flow. I think breakevens are one of the more optimistically priced assets related to the U.K. economy, right? Expecting inflation to remain at levels, really similar levels predicted in 2007.

JOHNSON: Matt?

MILLER: All right. That was a fun speed round, we should do that -- we should do that more often. Andrew Sheets from Morgan Stanley is going to stay with us. We have a lot more questions for him.

(BREAK)

MILLER: Joining me now is Bloomberg Businessweek senior editor here in Berlin, David Rocks. Andrew Sheets, chief cross asset strategist at Morgan Stanley is still with us in London as our guest host for the hour. David, first off, tell -- tell me about the city series, what prompted this, what's it about, what's the cities issue?

ROCKS: Well, there's -- there's 32 cities in the world now with more than 10 million people. More and more people around the world are moving to cities, and obviously, cities are a hugely important -- it's where people live now, right? More and more, especially in the developing world, so we wanted to look some of the problems ...

MILLER: Some (inaudible) rural and into the urban basically, yes.

ROCKS: Yes. We look at the kind of problems that these cities are having and how they can keep themselves from being strangled by their growth.

JOHNSON: It's interesting that -- that Moscow has -- has sort of changed so much and so quickly, David. It's gone in 20 years from being this incredibly sort of dower, difficult city to live in, to being this kind of sort of, standout metropolis, and that journey has been quite an incredible one. Just in terms of the momentum that Moscow has right now, how would you describe it?

ROCKS: Well, I think that a couple things are at play here. The -- the -- the numbers that we're about to see toady are probably going to show that consumption remains the main driver of the Russian economy. And you're never going to -- you're going to see that mostly in Moscow, or more -- more -- more clearly in Moscow. It's a -- it's a pretty wealthy city, and there are a lot of people there with a lot of money, and the city has a -- brought a lot of tax revenue, so they're spending it on making the place a nicer place to live.

MILLER: What is -- what are some of the other cities that you focused on?

ROCKS: Well, we looked at -- we looked at bike-sharing in Beijing, we've got somebody who went out and sort of tried that, and it's, you know, Beijing used to be a city where there were tons and tons of bikes, and now it's become -- for years, they sort of focused on cars, now they're kind of looking at bikes again, so that's a nice -- that's a nice view. We looked at New York City, how cities have a difficult time knowing what's actually underneath them. In New York City, you know, obviously, everybody knows where, you know, 57th and Park is, but do they actually know what's underneath there? And the answer is no. Not just the subways, but all of the conduits and things like that, and that's a huge problem for cities around the world. So there's a guy who's creating a -- like an underground map of New York City that we profile nicely, so ...

JOHNSON: That sounds amazing. (inaudible) can't wait to see that. Andrew, let's bring you into this conversation, Andrew Sheets. GDP data out of Russia a little bit later on. Where does Russia stack up in the -- the -- in the options that you see in front of you? It's long being perceived as being a kind of oil trade, but -- but that -- that kind of story has been diluted a little bit. How do you -- how do you see Russia stacking up? It's isolated increasingly, it finds itself on the wrong side of the political story increasingly. Where do we go with it as an investment, though?

SHEETS: Well, look, I mean, obviously, this is a country, right, where there's the political side of things, and then there's the economic side of things, right? Politically, it -- it is clearly going to be in the head -- it is clearly in the headlines and will continue to be in the headlines with some of the things coming out of the U.S. as well as the continued volatility in oil prices. But if we look at the macro economics, those in the country have been improving. Inflation has been moderating, the budget balances have been getting better thanks to the weaker ruble, and we think that credit profile of the country has actually been getting somewhat stronger while the currency remains very inexpensive, and real rates in Russia are some of the highest anywhere. So it's -- it's been very prudential, it's been very cautious since monetary policy, it's been very conservative which we think is helpful, and that's one of the reasons why generally speaking, we see the risk reward in Russian fixed income as more favorable than many other countries in EM.

MILLER: All right. Very interesting call and very interesting edition, can't wait to see it. David Rocks our senior editor here in Berlin, thanks so much for joining us. Andrew Sheets, chief crosset (ph) strategist at Morgan Stanley is our guest host for the hour, he's going to stick with us as we tack tech. Is tech disrupting the inflation theory? We'll discuss how Amazon is factoring in today's consumer price reading and decisions. This is Bloomberg.

(BREAK)

JOHNSON: Joining us now, Julian David, he's the CEO of techUK. Andrew Sheets, chief cross asset strategist at Morgan Stanley is still with us. Julian, first of all, I -- I -- we're going to spend a lot of the day talking about inflation. Tech we know, is a disinflationary factor. It -- look at Moore's Law, look at all kinds of different factors, tech generally has that -- has that impact, and it improves productivity and -- and -- and therefore, filters back in that way as well. When you look at the incredibly low, sort of, inflationary environment that we have at the moment, do you think tech is, and -- and companies like Amazon are responsible partly for that?

DAVID: Yes. I think -- I mean, there's -- there's historical trend on this. I mean, technology has applied to all industries, has brought prices down and changed the balance. So if you just look at the move from craft industries to manufactured goods, there's a huge reduction there. You look at what happened in the emergence of China as a manufacturing powerhouse driven by tech, the -- the use of robotics and so on. What's happening now of course, is that's also now being applied to services, and it's the internet which is -- which is powering that. So you're having the ability first of all, to use assets much more productively, secondly, to increase the pull of assets. If you look at things like, you know, Airbnb bringing trillions of dollars worth of flexible accommodation into the market, that makes a big -- big -- big change. So yes, tech is -- is a major force behind better pricing, better offers, more flexible offers for -- for consumers.

MILLER: Julian, are we talking about two different things, though that both are contributing to lower prices or a lack of price growth? On the one hand, you got the sharing economy, and basically, that's allowing people to pay lower prices for services that the -- the providers used to charge a premium for, now, for example, if you're a driver or offering a room for rent, you just don't make that much money on it -- on that service. On the other hand, you've got a company that is such a behemoth, it's willing to not make a profit in order to eat up the market share that everybody else used to enjoy. Aren't those two different issues?

DAVID: Well, there's a consistent thread which is, it's technology that enables that kind of approach, so you know, if you -- if you just look at conventional retailing, the technology around superstores, which -- which came into place, the ability to manage distribution using tech to do logistics, you know, really gave you the opportunity to operate at a larger scale with lower margins, better pricing for the consumer. And the internet allows you to do that on a bigger scale, so -- so I really think technology is a driver of this, and you're going to see this across services now.

MILLER: Well, tech -- on the one hand is technology, on the other hand, if you look at company like Amazon, if you look at a company like Uber, it's the willingness not to make any money in order to knock the other guy out of business and control the entire market, no?

DAVID: Well, the -- the ability to take a long-term look at this, the -- the willingness of investors to -- to go with and the ability to finance this stuff is clearly, you know, a necessary part of it. But at the end of the day, you still got to back to the performance. You know, if they're able to get a better performance by using technology in a smarter way by, you know, managing assets at -- at -- at lower returns, then that's going to give them the opportunity to -- to grow, and that's going to drive again, you know, investor interest.

JOHNSON: Andrew, is the Phillips curve broken because of Amazon?

SHEETS: Well, you know, I think it's interesting, right? So our interest rate strategists have looked at this and they find that the Phillips curve is actually still in place and still working in -- in parts of the economy, and just not working in others in part, due to technology disruption and some of these other factors. So I think it is still there, and I think it's also important, I think as Julian alluded to, which is, we need to differentiate between this low inflation and the function of a negative demand shock which is very concerning for markets and a sign that growth is weaker than expected, or a positive supply shock, i.e., more technology coming online, more supply which is a positive. So again, I would say that our interpretation is more towards the latter, is more that some of the inflation dynamics that we're seeing are more of a function of a positive supply dynamic than a weak demand dynamic. But again, I think that is a real key debate for markets.

MILLER: What about the -- I wonder how long investors are willing to put money behind a company that doesn't make any money, as long as it grows revenue and takes market share? Is that -- I mean, is there really no set time limit for that because Amazon's been doing it for 20 years?

DAVID: Yes, I think -- I think, Matt, that's a very interesting question, you know, it's one that has been asked ever since they got going. You know, I used to work a lot with conventional retailers. You know, the conventional wisdom was, this can't last. Conventional wisdom, Andrew, sometimes doesn't work out, does it? And it certainly didn't in this case.

MILLER: Andrew, what do you think?

SHEETS: Well -- well, look, I mean, again, I think that's -- that's right. So look, I -- I won't comment specifically on -- on the company itself, but -- but this has been a trend that's been in place for -- for a long period of time. You know, I -- I also think that you have a market where, you know, we just talked in a previous segment, I mean, people are very willing to buy gold despite the fact that it has a negative income. So -- so the site -- I mean, one of the -- the -- the fallouts of low interest rates is that the opportunity cost of investing in a business or investing in an asset does not necessarily earn any money right now, that opportunity cost is a lot lower. And so you know, there -- there are some positive dynamics of that and there are potentially some negative dynamics of that.

JOHNSON: We'll leave it there. Gentlemen, thank you very much indeed. Andrew, you're going to stick around, but we're going to give you a 10-minute break. You're going to join Matt and I on Bloomberg Radio very shortly at the top of the hour. Andrew Sheets joining us from Morgan Stanley. We're going to carry on the conversation with Julian David, he is the CEO of techUK, we need to talk about what is happening with Brexit. Brexit optimism, Theresa may sticking to her (inaudible) timetable despite doubts within her cabinet. We're going to discuss what that means to the tech landscape. We should probably also talk about gender within the tech landscape as well. This is Bloomberg.

(BREAK)

MILLER: I want to get back to the tech theme though that we've been discussing. Theresa May still aims to stick to her two-year Brexit deal goal despite members of her own cabinet expressing doubts over the timetable. Last month, the international trade secretary, Liam Fox called this optimistic, while chancellor of the exchequer, Philip Hammond envisions a three-year bridging period.

Julian David, CEO of techUK is still with us. And Julian, we were talking about -- we were talking about tech issues as far as market share profitability and inflation in the U.S. is concerned, let's talk about tech issues as far as employment, location, positioning, and Brexit is concerned. We had an interesting story earlier this week about how media companies may need to look outside the U.K. because of licensing issues. Do you see the same concern at tech company headquarters as we do with bank headquarters in the U.K. post-Brexit?

DAVID: Absolutely, Matt. You know, the -- the U.K. tech industry was very clear in the run up to the referendum that the best solution was staying in the European Union, and since the referendum which of course, the democratic process, we accept that, we've been very clear that we need to be very close to the single market, we need to have access to this and we need to concentrate on three areas which are really concerning to tech. The first one is skills and talent. We're already seeing it difficult to get the sort of talent that we need to be the global leader in tech here in the U.K., and secondly, is the -- the whole regulatory and customs, and equivalents regime which some call a customs union, but it's a bit more than that in tech because it also covers services and it covers other things.

And -- and we need to have that as close to Europe as possible, and the last one is data. You know, if we don't have a data adequacy agreement with the European Union, then it will be impossible for tech companies to operate with European citizens' data. So that's a big deal, that's a cliff edge. That's a -- that's a , you know, fall-off-the-clip thing.

JOHNSON: The -- the data is here, it was massive. Google's just won approval to -- to build its new London headquarters next to the -- to the old one up in King's Cross. Aren't you surprised that they're building that?

DAVID: No, because U.K. is a big tech opportunity, big tech market, big tech center. You know, we are globally up there speaking of data. Well, if you think about it, you know, these kind of things are set against an industry that's growing, so making that kind of investment in a big economy like the U.K probably still makes sense. But also of course, they don't know exactly how this is going to turn out, so we're trying and hoping the government's going to -- going to get this right, you know. Our (inaudible) hash tag say get it right, because if we don't ...

JOHNSON: That sounds nice.

DAVID: Yes. If we don't -- you know, so it's encouraging to hear the kind of stuff that's being talked about -- about our transition. We're saying we need a long runway to make, you know, to land this Brexit claim. It's not going to be done in what is left, a year? And I know it's two years in theory, but really, you -- you need to get these things done, otherwise, people will have to make decisions and they'll have to move stuff. So what we need is that -- that transition period, and we need a data adequacy position without a doubt. Not just us, but all the industries is (inaudible) on data.

MILLER: Julian, I want to ask about -- I mean, we know that there's a need for more biological diversity at tech companies in the U.S., it's something, you know, Bloomberg is a company who feels very strongly about, and we've been reporting on it for -- for years now. What about ideological diversity? Is it possible to have a difference of opinion in these companies, or are they really, just -- have they really just turned into an echo chamber? Because most recently, you know, one employee was fired for voicing a different opinion, and now, (inaudible) he wants to find a safe space for people to have free speech.

DAVID: Look, obviously, I don't have the detail and I can't comment on an individual company situation, but clearly, you know, tech thrives on innovation, it thrives on -- on -- on diversity, and that's diversity of opinion and diversity of -- of people in the market. But it must be said, we all understand there is a problem around the participation of -- of female workforce in tech. It's only about 17 percent. You know, you -- you can't carry on with that in the face of what is a continuing skill shortage, plus, at the end of the day, tech has a bigger roles (inaudible) a supplier, it's also part of society, so women are contributing (inaudible) that's not going to be good.

JOHNSON: We're going to carry on that conversation on Bloomberg Radio. Surveillance is next. Matt and I are going to Bloomberg Radio.

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

urn:contentItem:5P8C-J391-DY0W-43JM-00000-00Andrew Sheets and Julian David Intvd on Bloomberg TV2017-08-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:11:39ZLexisNexisAndrew Sheets and Julian David Intvd on Bloomberg TVLanhamFULL TEXT

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

ANDREW SHEETS, CHIEF CROSS ASSET STRATEGIST, MORGAN STANLEY & JULIAN DAVID, CEO, TECHUK, ARE INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TV

AUGUST 11, 2017

SPEAKERS: ANDREW SHEETS, CHIEF CROSS ASSET STRATEGIST, MORGAN STANLEY

JULIAN DAVID, CEO, TECHUK

GUY JOHNSON, BLOOMBERG NEWS

MATT MILLER, BLOOMBERG NEWS

ALAN CRAWFORD, BLOOMBERG NEWS

DAVID ROCKS, SENIOR EDITOR, BLOOMBERG BUSINESSWEEK

[*] JOHNSON: Joining us now, Andrew Sheets, chief cross asset strategist at Morgan Stanley. Good morning. Which is the bigger factor for the market today, inflation number coming out a little bit later on or what's happening on the geopolitical front?

SHEETS: I think geopolitics have really taken -- taken the lead here. I think if you would ask investors on Monday, it was absolutely around CPI, it would be absolutely around, you know, the timing of -- of a Fed action and what we might see, but I think the moves -- the rhetoric that we've seen out of Washington and North Korea, that has I think, been the predominant factor now dominating markets.

JOHNSON: Just to kind of take a step back, nobody's here, these are thinned markets. The president's, theoretically, on holiday, is it just the fact that -- that we are in holiday liquidity sort of environments in - - in various asset classes that is -- that is driving this kind of pickup in volatility?

SHEETS: Well, look, I mean, I think that's -- that's actually a really important point, right? As -- as silly as it might sound that kind of where people currently are, are a bigger factor than some of these macroeconomic events. The fact that August is a time when a lot of people are out that we are seeing the -- the president and his staff are not in the White House, that investors often have to deal with markets with thinner liquidity and thinner markets in August, has a tendency to exacerbate moves. And I think that's maybe one reason why historically, you tend to see somewhat weaker market performance in August relative to other months.

MILLER: So you think we're going to see a pickup then in volatility? Are we going to -- I mean, the other day, we were making a massive deal about the S&P 500 being down 0.24 percent, are we going to start seeing 1 percent moves again, real -- real range?

SHEETS: So I would actually be a little bit skeptical about that. So look, you -- you obviously have had a big shock to a market that was incredibly calm. So right, as of Monday, the 10-year -- the 10-day realized volatility for the S&P 500 was just 2 or 3 percent, it was the lowest in 50 years. So it's definitely a shock for the market to go from that level of calm to what we have currently, but if I think about the factors that are still in place, I think you still are dealing with relatively solid global growth, you're s till dealing with very dovish policy. Most of the positioning metrics that we track don't suggest investors are unusually long. I think all of those things argue against a really large regime shift into kind of daily 1, 1.5 percent moves.

MILLER: One of the things -- one of the factoids I saw recently in a story about how quant hedge fund strategies are failing because there's not enough dumb money out there is that, retail investors' cash levels are at the lowest they've been in a decade. If they've -- if they've already -- if they're already so invested or it doesn't matter I guess, where they're invested, do you expect them to maybe be pulling money out then? Especially as we see highs like this?

SHEETS: Well, look, I mean, I think this is a debate where you can find data on -- on either side, so I guess what -- what I find a little bit more encouraging is that if we look at flows into the equity market, especially the U.S. equity market, those flows have still been incredibly modest, not just over the last year, but really over the last eight years. So I don't yet see evidence, and I think, you know, our -- our U.S. equity strategist very much agree with this. We don't see evidence that retail has rushed a lot of money into the market recently that it would then need to pull out. So -- so look, there's always -- you know, I certainly wouldn't say that investors were negative, you know, in the last several months, but we don't see that sign of excessive stock buying that would lead we think, to excessive retail selling.

JOHNSON: This is definitely the wrong chart, what I'm about to show here. Let's talk about -- a little bit about the skew and what's going on. The market is -- is positioning itself to buy kind of downside protection at the moment. The -- the -- the line goes up, as it goes up, basically, that's signaling that the market is trying to buy downside protection. Is that an opportunity do you think at this point when you're looking at what is happening with the SPX? Would you be going the other way?

SHEETS: Yes. Well, look, I think that's -- that's a really important part, right? So as much as, you know, the -- the focus has been on the rhetoric in Korea or the -- the daily moves in the S&P that the much bigger moves we've had over the last 48 hours have really been in the VIX, and volatility on the VIX, right, which have moved significantly more than you would usually expect. And you know, that suggest that that's maybe where the real market pressure is, where some of the real market inefficiency might be, and it's not just mood volatility significantly, but as you mentioned it's moved skew significantly, right? So you've seen the volatility on puts rise to relatively unusually high levels versus calls. So you know, in our view, probably, the best way to lean against that would be, that that makes calls relatively cheap, because that's the volatility that's lowest relative to everything else.

MILLER: All right, Andrew, you're going to stick with us here. Andrew Sheets is chief -- chief cross asset strategist at Morgan Stanley. There's a lot to talk about on a day like today when we see actual movement in equity index.

(BREAK)

MILLER: Joining us here to talk about that in Berlin is our government editor, Alan Crawford. Andrew Sheets is with us as well, chief cross asset strategist at Morgan Stanley. Alan, let's talk -- touch on the first point. And I think a lot of Germans find it hard to sort of discern now between the policies of the two parties. What would change say, if the SPD won and Martin Schultz came in Angela Merkel's place, policy-wise?

CRAWFORD: Well, at the moment, that looks like a big if, but it would also depend very much on what kind of coalition he could form. At the moment, that latest poll suggests it would have to be something like a four-way coalition, so it's extremely hard to see. Nevertheless, what we could see is that Martin Schulz as a former president of the European Parliament, he's somewhat more open to certainly common European policies, so perhaps more in terms of defense sharing and crucially perhaps, more in terms of integrating the Eurozone. Merkel has also made some comments about that, that she's open to some of these moves by the -- the French president, but the -- the assumption is that Schultz would probably be somewhat more open. Whether that extends to debt sharing is a different issue, but yes, more open.

JOHNSON: So it's hers to lose at this point in time, now that I think it's clear judging by the polling, Alan, so what risks is she running, kind of -- and -- and how does that relate to the strategy that we're seeing?

CRAWFORD: Well, as we just mentioned, we're talking about party certainly, party officials are somewhat concerned about any -- any hint of complacency. Not so much on Merkel's behalf but more like on behalf of the party and the party apparatus. Remember of course, when Merkel first ran for Chancellor in 2005, she was running Gerhard Schroder who was the incumbent -- he was the chancellor, and she managed to -- to squander a lead of more than 20 percentage points. He of course, was an extremely adept campaigner, and it was -- and in the end, she one by one point. Nevertheless, she is embarking on 50-stop campaign tour, so I think it's hard to accuse her of complacency at this point.

MILLER: You're welcome to refresh or memories. I mean, not all of us wrote a book on Angela Merkel. I should point out that Alan wrote a book on Merkel, so he knows this subject better than anyone. Andrew, let me ask you from an investor's perspective, is this an important election for you to pay close attention to? I mean, do you have to be as concerned about this as you did the French elections or the Dutch elections, or can you pretty much consider this a confirmation of Angela Merkel's fourth term and that kind consistency is good for you as an investor?

SHEETS: Well, look, so I -- I think about it as -- as follows. I think in terms of the actual outcome, I think markets are probably going to focus on it somewhat less because of what we've already seen in the Netherlands and France, and because I think there's a broad majority within Germany that -- that is pro-Europe, pro the E.U., and is pushing towards more integrations, that whole argument that there might be some faction pushing for something different now, seems significantly less likely. But I think what markets will focus on is this idea that at the core of Europe in -- between France and Germany, this idea of really working for a stronger European union, are pushed towards reform that we might not have seen in a way that we have in a number of years. I think that's structurally bullish for the euro, that's been one of the key calls of our FX strategy team, and the euro remains very undervalued on a long-term basis, and so this is a multi-year call in our view, for a stronger euro.

JOHNSON: Alan, where does the risk lie to Europe in this election? There does seem to be this sense that coming out of this, we're going to see a new impetus towards a closer integration. Now, that's started by Mr. Macron, but the German election's a pivotal piece in all of this. Does the coalition formation have a bearing on that? I.e., if she's in -- in -- in coalition with the -- with the FDP for instance, would that dilute that drive?

CRAWFORD: This is exactly the point that we will be focusing on during our coverage. The -- the latest poll for example, showed that Merkel has various coalition options which could in turn strengthen her hand in negotiations which remember, tend to last several weeks, if not months in Germany, after the election. Yes, the free democrats with whom had her second term coalition, they are -- they're more skeptical in terms of euro are bailouts, in terms of -- in terms of more integration in the Eurozone, that could put a break on some of her plans. Equally, the Greens are also in play. They are somewhat more enthusiastic about Eurozone integration and essentially, helping others. There could be a three-way coalition which is untested at the Federal level, or it could be an underground coalition.

MILLER: I remember when Joschka Fischer who was -- who's arguably, one of the most famous Greens said, forget about it, we prefer to wear dreadlocks, and they wouldn't be able to deal with that. Something like that, I'm paraphrasing. But it is a possible coalition. What's the -- what's the -- what are the dangers to Merkel here, and what could bring her down in the next six weeks? Is diesel a problem for her, is -- is the refugee, I would say crisis, but it's no longer a crisis here in Germany, is the influx that we saw a couple of years ago of refugees a problem for her? What could bring her down?

CRAWFORD: That's definitely an Achilles heel. If there were -- if there were to be some massive influx to Germany such as we saw two years ago when there was a genuine crisis and a buildup of people at Germany's border, that -- at the moment, the focus is on Italy, so it looks somewhat less likely, but nevertheless, if she was forced to make some kind of snap decision about that, then that would be a problem for her. Who that would benefit, whether it would benefit her main rival is another issue. Certainly, there's also, if there were any sort of repeat of the -- of the sexual attacks in Cologne, that was a devastating issue related to the crisis. Of course, terrorism is always -- is always lurking. Again, it's hard to see how these issues could -- could boost support for her -- her -- her main rival. The one thing I would say is, there is a potential that support for the -- the far right, anti-immigration AfD Party, perhaps the polls are underestimating that. I'm not saying it could win, but there is importantly the level, higher.

MILLER: The polls here though, historically more accurate than they are say, in Britain. Alan Crawford, our European government editor here in Berlin. I should point out that he co-wrote the book, "Angela Merkel: A Chancellor Forged in Crisis" with Tony Czuczka who also works with us here in Berlin. Andrew Sheets is the chief crosset (ph) asset -- cross asset strategist at Morgan Stanley, he's going to stick with us, our guest host for the hour.

(BREAK)

JOHNSON: Let's turn our attention now to market risks and how investors should be positioning themselves. Alan Sheets chief cross asset strategist at Morgan Stanley is still with us, and let's talk about some of the calls that we should be making right now. Andrew, the world is long euro, is that the right call?

SHEETS: Yes. So we think from an equity perspective, not necessarily. Graham Secker, our European equity strategist has been somewhat cautious over the last several months on concerns around what the strong euro will mean for earnings. Now, I think what's quite interesting is just really, over the last day, some of the tactical indicators that his team follows have finally dipped down into bi-territory, so that's something we have to watch in terms of our relative preferences. Currently, the U.S. and Japan are our top global equity markets, but Europe has underperformed recently, and that's something we have to monitor.

MILLER: Why are you long European value versus growth right now, Andrew?

SHEETS: Sure. So look, I think the -- the argument for Europe is that you have an improving economy and that valuations are attractive, that I think is the dominant narrative that I hear for European equities. I think if we look deeper into the market, most of the value in Europe lies within value, it lies within the financial sector, it lies within the energy sector, it lies within some of the other parts that make up the value index. So in our view, that's the part of the market where the majority of the cheapness of Europe is concentrated. It's starting to get some positive momentum on a long-term basis, it's underperformed really, for a decade and we think that's starting to turn around in our long-term view.

JOHNSON: Why are you short U.K. inflation? Why are you short the U.K. 10-year breakeven?

SHEETS: Sure. So -- so we think Brexit remains a challenging dynamic, right, and you're going to have U.K. politicians coming back from their holidays, going into negotiations in September, and we expect potentially more negative news flow. I think breakevens are one of the more optimistically priced assets related to the U.K. economy, right? Expecting inflation to remain at levels, really similar levels predicted in 2007.

JOHNSON: Matt?

MILLER: All right. That was a fun speed round, we should do that -- we should do that more often. Andrew Sheets from Morgan Stanley is going to stay with us. We have a lot more questions for him.

(BREAK)

MILLER: Joining me now is Bloomberg Businessweek senior editor here in Berlin, David Rocks. Andrew Sheets, chief cross asset strategist at Morgan Stanley is still with us in London as our guest host for the hour. David, first off, tell -- tell me about the city series, what prompted this, what's it about, what's the cities issue?

ROCKS: Well, there's -- there's 32 cities in the world now with more than 10 million people. More and more people around the world are moving to cities, and obviously, cities are a hugely important -- it's where people live now, right? More and more, especially in the developing world, so we wanted to look some of the problems ...

MILLER: Some (inaudible) rural and into the urban basically, yes.

ROCKS: Yes. We look at the kind of problems that these cities are having and how they can keep themselves from being strangled by their growth.

JOHNSON: It's interesting that -- that Moscow has -- has sort of changed so much and so quickly, David. It's gone in 20 years from being this incredibly sort of dower, difficult city to live in, to being this kind of sort of, standout metropolis, and that journey has been quite an incredible one. Just in terms of the momentum that Moscow has right now, how would you describe it?

ROCKS: Well, I think that a couple things are at play here. The -- the -- the numbers that we're about to see toady are probably going to show that consumption remains the main driver of the Russian economy. And you're never going to -- you're going to see that mostly in Moscow, or more -- more -- more clearly in Moscow. It's a -- it's a pretty wealthy city, and there are a lot of people there with a lot of money, and the city has a -- brought a lot of tax revenue, so they're spending it on making the place a nicer place to live.

MILLER: What is -- what are some of the other cities that you focused on?

ROCKS: Well, we looked at -- we looked at bike-sharing in Beijing, we've got somebody who went out and sort of tried that, and it's, you know, Beijing used to be a city where there were tons and tons of bikes, and now it's become -- for years, they sort of focused on cars, now they're kind of looking at bikes again, so that's a nice -- that's a nice view. We looked at New York City, how cities have a difficult time knowing what's actually underneath them. In New York City, you know, obviously, everybody knows where, you know, 57th and Park is, but do they actually know what's underneath there? And the answer is no. Not just the subways, but all of the conduits and things like that, and that's a huge problem for cities around the world. So there's a guy who's creating a -- like an underground map of New York City that we profile nicely, so ...

JOHNSON: That sounds amazing. (inaudible) can't wait to see that. Andrew, let's bring you into this conversation, Andrew Sheets. GDP data out of Russia a little bit later on. Where does Russia stack up in the -- the -- in the options that you see in front of you? It's long being perceived as being a kind of oil trade, but -- but that -- that kind of story has been diluted a little bit. How do you -- how do you see Russia stacking up? It's isolated increasingly, it finds itself on the wrong side of the political story increasingly. Where do we go with it as an investment, though?

SHEETS: Well, look, I mean, obviously, this is a country, right, where there's the political side of things, and then there's the economic side of things, right? Politically, it -- it is clearly going to be in the head -- it is clearly in the headlines and will continue to be in the headlines with some of the things coming out of the U.S. as well as the continued volatility in oil prices. But if we look at the macro economics, those in the country have been improving. Inflation has been moderating, the budget balances have been getting better thanks to the weaker ruble, and we think that credit profile of the country has actually been getting somewhat stronger while the currency remains very inexpensive, and real rates in Russia are some of the highest anywhere. So it's -- it's been very prudential, it's been very cautious since monetary policy, it's been very conservative which we think is helpful, and that's one of the reasons why generally speaking, we see the risk reward in Russian fixed income as more favorable than many other countries in EM.

MILLER: All right. Very interesting call and very interesting edition, can't wait to see it. David Rocks our senior editor here in Berlin, thanks so much for joining us. Andrew Sheets, chief crosset (ph) strategist at Morgan Stanley is our guest host for the hour, he's going to stick with us as we tack tech. Is tech disrupting the inflation theory? We'll discuss how Amazon is factoring in today's consumer price reading and decisions. This is Bloomberg.

(BREAK)

JOHNSON: Joining us now, Julian David, he's the CEO of techUK. Andrew Sheets, chief cross asset strategist at Morgan Stanley is still with us. Julian, first of all, I -- I -- we're going to spend a lot of the day talking about inflation. Tech we know, is a disinflationary factor. It -- look at Moore's Law, look at all kinds of different factors, tech generally has that -- has that impact, and it improves productivity and -- and -- and therefore, filters back in that way as well. When you look at the incredibly low, sort of, inflationary environment that we have at the moment, do you think tech is, and -- and companies like Amazon are responsible partly for that?

DAVID: Yes. I think -- I mean, there's -- there's historical trend on this. I mean, technology has applied to all industries, has brought prices down and changed the balance. So if you just look at the move from craft industries to manufactured goods, there's a huge reduction there. You look at what happened in the emergence of China as a manufacturing powerhouse driven by tech, the -- the use of robotics and so on. What's happening now of course, is that's also now being applied to services, and it's the internet which is -- which is powering that. So you're having the ability first of all, to use assets much more productively, secondly, to increase the pull of assets. If you look at things like, you know, Airbnb bringing trillions of dollars worth of flexible accommodation into the market, that makes a big -- big -- big change. So yes, tech is -- is a major force behind better pricing, better offers, more flexible offers for -- for consumers.

MILLER: Julian, are we talking about two different things, though that both are contributing to lower prices or a lack of price growth? On the one hand, you got the sharing economy, and basically, that's allowing people to pay lower prices for services that the -- the providers used to charge a premium for, now, for example, if you're a driver or offering a room for rent, you just don't make that much money on it -- on that service. On the other hand, you've got a company that is such a behemoth, it's willing to not make a profit in order to eat up the market share that everybody else used to enjoy. Aren't those two different issues?

DAVID: Well, there's a consistent thread which is, it's technology that enables that kind of approach, so you know, if you -- if you just look at conventional retailing, the technology around superstores, which -- which came into place, the ability to manage distribution using tech to do logistics, you know, really gave you the opportunity to operate at a larger scale with lower margins, better pricing for the consumer. And the internet allows you to do that on a bigger scale, so -- so I really think technology is a driver of this, and you're going to see this across services now.

MILLER: Well, tech -- on the one hand is technology, on the other hand, if you look at company like Amazon, if you look at a company like Uber, it's the willingness not to make any money in order to knock the other guy out of business and control the entire market, no?

DAVID: Well, the -- the ability to take a long-term look at this, the -- the willingness of investors to -- to go with and the ability to finance this stuff is clearly, you know, a necessary part of it. But at the end of the day, you still got to back to the performance. You know, if they're able to get a better performance by using technology in a smarter way by, you know, managing assets at -- at -- at lower returns, then that's going to give them the opportunity to -- to grow, and that's going to drive again, you know, investor interest.

JOHNSON: Andrew, is the Phillips curve broken because of Amazon?

SHEETS: Well, you know, I think it's interesting, right? So our interest rate strategists have looked at this and they find that the Phillips curve is actually still in place and still working in -- in parts of the economy, and just not working in others in part, due to technology disruption and some of these other factors. So I think it is still there, and I think it's also important, I think as Julian alluded to, which is, we need to differentiate between this low inflation and the function of a negative demand shock which is very concerning for markets and a sign that growth is weaker than expected, or a positive supply shock, i.e., more technology coming online, more supply which is a positive. So again, I would say that our interpretation is more towards the latter, is more that some of the inflation dynamics that we're seeing are more of a function of a positive supply dynamic than a weak demand dynamic. But again, I think that is a real key debate for markets.

MILLER: What about the -- I wonder how long investors are willing to put money behind a company that doesn't make any money, as long as it grows revenue and takes market share? Is that -- I mean, is there really no set time limit for that because Amazon's been doing it for 20 years?

DAVID: Yes, I think -- I think, Matt, that's a very interesting question, you know, it's one that has been asked ever since they got going. You know, I used to work a lot with conventional retailers. You know, the conventional wisdom was, this can't last. Conventional wisdom, Andrew, sometimes doesn't work out, does it? And it certainly didn't in this case.

MILLER: Andrew, what do you think?

SHEETS: Well -- well, look, I mean, again, I think that's -- that's right. So look, I -- I won't comment specifically on -- on the company itself, but -- but this has been a trend that's been in place for -- for a long period of time. You know, I -- I also think that you have a market where, you know, we just talked in a previous segment, I mean, people are very willing to buy gold despite the fact that it has a negative income. So -- so the site -- I mean, one of the -- the -- the fallouts of low interest rates is that the opportunity cost of investing in a business or investing in an asset does not necessarily earn any money right now, that opportunity cost is a lot lower. And so you know, there -- there are some positive dynamics of that and there are potentially some negative dynamics of that.

JOHNSON: We'll leave it there. Gentlemen, thank you very much indeed. Andrew, you're going to stick around, but we're going to give you a 10-minute break. You're going to join Matt and I on Bloomberg Radio very shortly at the top of the hour. Andrew Sheets joining us from Morgan Stanley. We're going to carry on the conversation with Julian David, he is the CEO of techUK, we need to talk about what is happening with Brexit. Brexit optimism, Theresa may sticking to her (inaudible) timetable despite doubts within her cabinet. We're going to discuss what that means to the tech landscape. We should probably also talk about gender within the tech landscape as well. This is Bloomberg.

(BREAK)

MILLER: I want to get back to the tech theme though that we've been discussing. Theresa May still aims to stick to her two-year Brexit deal goal despite members of her own cabinet expressing doubts over the timetable. Last month, the international trade secretary, Liam Fox called this optimistic, while chancellor of the exchequer, Philip Hammond envisions a three-year bridging period.

Julian David, CEO of techUK is still with us. And Julian, we were talking about -- we were talking about tech issues as far as market share profitability and inflation in the U.S. is concerned, let's talk about tech issues as far as employment, location, positioning, and Brexit is concerned. We had an interesting story earlier this week about how media companies may need to look outside the U.K. because of licensing issues. Do you see the same concern at tech company headquarters as we do with bank headquarters in the U.K. post-Brexit?

DAVID: Absolutely, Matt. You know, the -- the U.K. tech industry was very clear in the run up to the referendum that the best solution was staying in the European Union, and since the referendum which of course, the democratic process, we accept that, we've been very clear that we need to be very close to the single market, we need to have access to this and we need to concentrate on three areas which are really concerning to tech. The first one is skills and talent. We're already seeing it difficult to get the sort of talent that we need to be the global leader in tech here in the U.K., and secondly, is the -- the whole regulatory and customs, and equivalents regime which some call a customs union, but it's a bit more than that in tech because it also covers services and it covers other things.

And -- and we need to have that as close to Europe as possible, and the last one is data. You know, if we don't have a data adequacy agreement with the European Union, then it will be impossible for tech companies to operate with European citizens' data. So that's a big deal, that's a cliff edge. That's a -- that's a , you know, fall-off-the-clip thing.

JOHNSON: The -- the data is here, it was massive. Google's just won approval to -- to build its new London headquarters next to the -- to the old one up in King's Cross. Aren't you surprised that they're building that?

DAVID: No, because U.K. is a big tech opportunity, big tech market, big tech center. You know, we are globally up there speaking of data. Well, if you think about it, you know, these kind of things are set against an industry that's growing, so making that kind of investment in a big economy like the U.K probably still makes sense. But also of course, they don't know exactly how this is going to turn out, so we're trying and hoping the government's going to -- going to get this right, you know. Our (inaudible) hash tag say get it right, because if we don't ...

JOHNSON: That sounds nice.

DAVID: Yes. If we don't -- you know, so it's encouraging to hear the kind of stuff that's being talked about -- about our transition. We're saying we need a long runway to make, you know, to land this Brexit claim. It's not going to be done in what is left, a year? And I know it's two years in theory, but really, you -- you need to get these things done, otherwise, people will have to make decisions and they'll have to move stuff. So what we need is that -- that transition period, and we need a data adequacy position without a doubt. Not just us, but all the industries is (inaudible) on data.

MILLER: Julian, I want to ask about -- I mean, we know that there's a need for more biological diversity at tech companies in the U.S., it's something, you know, Bloomberg is a company who feels very strongly about, and we've been reporting on it for -- for years now. What about ideological diversity? Is it possible to have a difference of opinion in these companies, or are they really, just -- have they really just turned into an echo chamber? Because most recently, you know, one employee was fired for voicing a different opinion, and now, (inaudible) he wants to find a safe space for people to have free speech.

DAVID: Look, obviously, I don't have the detail and I can't comment on an individual company situation, but clearly, you know, tech thrives on innovation, it thrives on -- on -- on diversity, and that's diversity of opinion and diversity of -- of people in the market. But it must be said, we all understand there is a problem around the participation of -- of female workforce in tech. It's only about 17 percent. You know, you -- you can't carry on with that in the face of what is a continuing skill shortage, plus, at the end of the day, tech has a bigger roles (inaudible) a supplier, it's also part of society, so women are contributing (inaudible) that's not going to be good.

JOHNSON: We're going to carry on that conversation on Bloomberg Radio. Surveillance is next. Matt and I are going to Bloomberg Radio.

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***
